newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuelan bolivar firms after Central Bank sales.
newsitem.headline: Venezuelan bolivar firms after Central Bank sales.

text.p: The Venezuelan bolivar closed slightly firmer at 467.75/477.75 per dollar Wednesday compared with 477.25/478.25 per dollar Tuesday, after the Central Bank intervened heavily to meet strong demand for foreign currency, traders said.
Quiet trading in the morning suddenly turned hectic as a series of rumors regarding instability in the country began to circulate.
"The session was full of all sorts of rumors," one trader said.
Interior Minister Jose Guillermo Andueza appealed to Venezuelans Wednesday to ignore a wave of rumors, which he said were baseless. He did not say what the rumors were.
In the afternoon "demand tripled and the Central Bank was active," another trader said.
"If the Central Bank had not intervened the rate would have shot up," he added.
Traders said the markets would be closely watching to President Rafael Caldera's annual address to legislators Thursday morning for any announcements which would calm market nerves.
